metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript Object Methods
General Methods

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Copies properties from a source object to a target object
// Creates an object from an existing object
// Returns an array of the key/value pairs of an object
// Creates an object from a list of keys/values
// Returns an array of the keys of an object
// Returns an array of the property values of an object
// Groups object elements according to a function

syntax_highlighting.text: // Copies properties from a source object to a target object
// Creates an object from an existing object
// Returns an array of the key/value pairs of an object
// Creates an object from a list of keys/values
// Returns an array of the keys of an object
// Returns an array of the property values of an object
// Groups object elements according to a function

content.code_html:
// Copies properties from a source object to a target object
 Object.assign(target, source)

// Creates an object from an existing object
 Object.create(object)

// Returns an array of the key/value pairs of an object
 Object.entries(object)

// Creates an object from a list of keys/values
 Object.fromEntries()

// Returns an array of the keys of an object
 Object.keys(object)

// Returns an array of the property values of an object
 Object.values(object)

// Groups object elements according to a function
 Object.groupBy(object, callback)

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Copies properties from a source object to a target object
// Creates an object from an existing object
// Returns an array of the key/value pairs of an object
// Creates an object from a list of keys/values
// Returns an array of the keys of an object
// Returns an array of the property values of an object
// Groups object elements according to a function

content.text: JavaScript Object.assign()
The Object.assign() method copies properties from one or more source objects to a target object.
content.html: The Object.assign() method copies properties from one or more source objects to a target object.

content.code_html:
// Create Target Object
 const person1 = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  age: 50,
  eyeColor: "blue"
};

// Create Source Object
 const person2 = {firstName: "Anne",lastName: "Smith"};

// Assign Source to Target
 Object.assign(person1, person2);

content.text: JavaScript Object.entries()
ECMAScript 2017 added the Object.entries() method to objects.
content.html: ECMAScript 2017 added the Object.entries() method to objects.

content.text: Object.entries() returns an array of the key/value pairs in an object:
content.html: Object.entries() returns an array of the key/value pairs in an object:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName : "John",
  lastName : "Doe",
  age : 50,
  eyeColor : "blue"
};

let text = Object.entries(person);

content.text: Object.entries() makes it simple to use objects in loops:
content.html: Object.entries() makes it simple to use objects in loops:

content.code_html:
const fruits = {Bananas:300, Oranges:200, Apples:500};

let text = "";
for (let [fruit, value] of Object.entries(fruits)) {
  text += fruit + ": " + value + "<br>";
}

content.text: Object.entries() also makes it simple to convert objects to maps:
content.html: Object.entries() also makes it simple to convert objects to maps:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const fruits = {Bananas:300, Oranges:200, Apples:500};

const myMap = new Map(Object.entries(fruits));

content.code:
const fruits = {Bananas:300, Oranges:200, Apples:500};

const myMap = new Map(Object.entries(fruits));

syntax_highlighting.text:
const fruits = {Bananas:300, Oranges:200, Apples:500};

const myMap = new Map(Object.entries(fruits));

content.code_html:
const fruits = {Bananas:300, Oranges:200, Apples:500};

const myMap = new Map(Object.entries(fruits));

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const fruits = {Bananas:300, Oranges:200, Apples:500};

const myMap = new Map(Object.entries(fruits));

content.text: Object.entries() is supported in all modern browsers since March 2017:
content.html: Object.entries() is supported in all modern browsers since March 2017:

content.text: JavaScript Object.fromEntries()
The fromEntries() method creates an object from a list of key/value pairs.
content.html: The fromEntries() method creates an object from a list of key/value pairs.

content.code_html:
const fruits = [
  ["apples", 300],
  ["pears", 900],
  ["bananas", 500]
];

const myObj = Object.fromEntries(fruits);

content.text: JavaScript Object.values()
Object.values() is similar to Object.entries() , but returns a single dimension array of the object values:
content.html: Object.values() is similar to Object.entries(), but returns a single dimension array of the object values:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName : "John",
  lastName : "Doe",
  age : 50,
  eyeColor : "blue"
};

let text = Object.values(person);

content.text: Object.values() is supported in all modern browsers since March 2017:
content.html: Object.values() is supported in all modern browsers since March 2017:

content.text: JavaScript Object.groupBy()
ES2024 added the Object.groupBy() method to JavaScript.
content.html: ES2024 added the Object.groupBy() method to JavaScript.

content.text: The Object.groupBy() method groups elements of an object according to string values returned from a callback function.
content.html: The Object.groupBy() method groups elements of an object according to string values returned from a callback function.

content.text: The Object.groupBy() method does not change the original object.
content.html: The Object.groupBy() method does not change the original object.

content.code_html:
// Create an Array
 const fruits = [
  {name:"apples", quantity:300},
  {name:"bananas", quantity:500},
  {name:"oranges", quantity:200},
  {name:"kiwi", quantity:150}
];

// Callback function to Group Elements
 function myCallback({ quantity }) {
  return quantity > 200 ? "ok" : "low";
}

// Group by Quantity
 const result = Object.groupBy(fruits, myCallback);

content.text: Browser Support
Object.groupby() is an ES2024 feature.
content.html: Object.groupby() is an ES2024 feature.

content.text: It is supported in new browsers since March 2024:
content.html: It is supported in new browsers since March 2024:

content.code_html:
Chrome 117 Edge 117 Firefox 119 Safari 17.4 Opera 103
Sep 2023 Sep 2023 Oct 2023 Okt 2024 May 2023

content.text: Warning
ES2024 features are relatively new.
content.html: ES2024 features are relatively new.

content.text: Older browsers may need an alternative code (Polyfill)
content.html: Older browsers may need an alternative code (Polyfill)

content.text: Object.groupBy() vs Map.groupBy()
The difference between Object.groupBy() and Map.groupBy() is:
content.html: The difference between Object.groupBy() and Map.groupBy() is:

content.text: Object.groupBy() groups elements into a JavaScript object.
content.html: Object.groupBy() groups elements into a JavaScript object.

content.text: Map.groupBy() groups elements into a Map object.
content.html: Map.groupBy() groups elements into a Map object.

content.text: JavaScript Object.keys()
The Object.keys() method returns an array with the keys of an object.
content.html: The Object.keys() method returns an array with the keys of an object.

content.code_html:
// Create an Object
 const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  age: 50,
  eyeColor: "blue"
};

// Get the Keys
 const keys = Object.keys(person);

content.text: JavaScript for...in Loop
The JavaScript for...in statement loops through the properties of an object.
content.html: The JavaScript for...in statement loops through the properties of an object.

content.text: Syntax

content.code_html:
for (let variable in object) {
  // code to be executed
}

content.text: The block of code inside of the for...in loop will be executed once for each property.
content.html: The block of code inside of the for...in loop will be executed once for each property.

content.text: Looping through the properties of an object:
content.html: Looping through the properties of an object:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  fname:" John",
  lname:" Doe",
  age: 25
};

for (let x in person) {
  txt += person[x];
}

content.html: Complete JavaScript Object Reference.

content.html: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all Object Properties and Methods.
